data.text: An inclined surface or roadway connecting different levels.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A mobile staircase by which passengers board and leave an aircraft.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A concave bend of a handrail where a sharp change in level or direction occurs, as at a stair landing.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To decrease in volume, amount, or rate.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: As the project ramped down, several employees were laid off.

data.text: To increase in volume, amount, or rate.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: The factory ramped up production to meet the increased demand.

data.text: To rush around or act in a threatening or violent manner.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To assume a threatening stance, as in rearing up on hindlegs.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To stand in the rampant position.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A plant (Allium tricoccum) of the eastern United States having small bulbs and young leaves that are edible and have a pungent onionlike flavor.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To rise by climbing or shooting up, as a plant; run or grow up rapidly; spring up in growth.
